dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: The pomegranate tree catches the first light, its leaves still damp from the night's coolness. You find Fatima already up, directing Zahra in folding the sleeping mats while Maryam clings to her mother's robe, half-awake.

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: You're up early. The Herawis tired you less than I expected.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: I slept well. Your lamb was excellent—Ibrahim said his wife couldn't match it.

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: Flattery from merchants.

dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: But she allows herself a small smile. You accept the tea she pours—strong, the way she knows you like it. For a moment, the domestic rhythm holds: the splash of water in the basin, Zahra's chatter, the distant call of the first prayer from the neighborhood mosque. Then you say what you came to say.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: Fatima. Last night, with the dinner—you managed something I couldn't have done alone. The food, the atmosphere, making them feel honored in our home. It worked.

dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: She looks at you now, those sharp dark eyes assessing.

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: You laugh despite yourself. She always cuts through the pleasantries.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: Sheikh Rostam told me something yesterday. He said quality gets respect, but presence—being there when a man's apprentice is sick or his wife dies—that's what gets you standing in the guild. I don't know who needs what. I don't know whose daughter is getting married or whose mother is dying. You do. Your mother does. The women's network sees everything.

dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: Fatima sets down her tea. She is quiet for a moment, watching Maryam toddle toward the herb garden.

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: You want me to be your spy in the Sabbaghan.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: I want you to be my partner. The way merchant wives work with their husbands. Not just running the household. Running the information.

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: I already told you about Old Mahmud's wife. About Karim's daughter's wedding.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: Yes. And I should have asked for that years ago. I need a list. Who matters in the guild. Who's having troubles. Who's rising, who's falling. Whose favor I should cultivate, and how. You know these things. Your mother knows them. I need to know them too.

dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: Fatima is silent for a long moment. When she speaks, her voice is different—lower, more serious.

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: My mother says you've changed these past months. More ambitious. More... reaching. She's not sure if it's good.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: What do you think?

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: I think you were always ambitious. You just hid it better. I'll make you a list. But you should understand something, Tahir.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: The women's network isn't free. If I start asking questions—pointed questions—about guild families, people will notice. They'll wonder why Fatima al-Sabbagh suddenly cares about who's sick and who's marrying. Some will think you're scheming. Some will think I'm scheming.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: Is that bad?

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: It depends on how you use what I tell you. If you visit Old Mahmud and bring honey, and his wife tells my mother you were kind, that's good. If you visit Old Mahmud and then try to poach his former apprentice, that's bad. The information has to serve relationships, not just advantage. Do you understand the difference?

dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: You think about this. It's the same lesson Sheikh Rostam was teaching, but from another angle.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: I think so.

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: Then I'll help you. Come home for the midday meal. I'll have the list ready, and my mother will come to tell you what she knows about the masters' households. She remembers things from when your father was alive—who helped Abbas, who didn't, who owes your family and who your family owes.

dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: Fatima adjusts her headscarf, preparing to see you off.

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: One more thing. Your friend Bahram.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: His wife Parvin talks. She's proud that you're teaching him the crimson. Very proud. She's told her sister, who told my mother's neighbor. By next week, the whole Sabbaghan will know you trust Bahram with your secrets.

dialogue.speaker: narrator
dialogue.text: You feel a chill despite the warming morning.

dialogue.speaker: tahir
dialogue.text: Is that bad?

dialogue.speaker: fatima
dialogue.text: It depends. If people think you're preparing Bahram to run the workshop while you travel, that's one story. If people think you're desperate, or dying, or losing your edge—that's another. Control the story before others tell it for you. When you see Bahram this morning, tell him exactly what you want people to think. He'll tell Parvin. She'll tell everyone.
